exoplanets.name: Kepler-186 f
exoplanets.short_description: Earth-size planet in the habitable zone of its red dwarf star.
exoplanets.description: Kepler‑186 f orbits a red M-type dwarf star every ~129.9 days. It was discovered in 2014 and is one of the first validated Earth-size exoplanets in the habitable zone. :contentReference[oaicite:0]{index=0}

exoplanets.name: Proxima Centauri b
exoplanets.short_description: Closest known exoplanet to Earth, orbiting in its star’s habitable zone.
exoplanets.description: Proxima Centauri b orbits the nearest star to the Sun, Proxima Centauri, at ~0.048 AU. Its mass is ~1.05 Earth masses (minimum), discovered via Doppler spectroscopy. :contentReference[oaicite:1]{index=1}

exoplanets.name: HD 209458 b (Osiris)
exoplanets.short_description: One of the first transiting exoplanets, a hot Jupiter.
exoplanets.description: HD 209458 b (Osiris) was discovered in 1999. It's a gas giant very close to its star (period ~3.5 days), and was among the first where an atmosphere was studied. :contentReference[oaicite:2]{index=2}

exoplanets.name: TRAPPIST-1 b
exoplanets.short_description: Very close-in planet in the TRAPPIST-1 system.
exoplanets.description: TRAPPIST-1 b is the innermost of the seven Earth-size planets in the TRAPPIST-1 system, orbiting its ultracool dwarf star very rapidly.

exoplanets.name: TRAPPIST-1 c
exoplanets.short_description: Second planet of TRAPPIST-1, a rocky world.
exoplanets.description: TRAPPIST-1 c orbits its host star in about 2.4 days and is slightly more massive than Earth.

exoplanets.name: TRAPPIST-1 d
exoplanets.short_description: One of the smaller TRAPPIST-1 planets.
exoplanets.description: TRAPPIST-1 d is one of the lighter and smaller planets in the TRAPPIST-1 system, with a very short orbital period.

exoplanets.name: TRAPPIST-1 e
exoplanets.short_description: Possibly the most habitable TRAPPIST-1 planet.
exoplanets.description: TRAPPIST-1 e lies in a part of its system that may allow for temperate conditions; it's one of the best candidates for habitability in the TRAPPIST-1 system.

exoplanets.name: GJ 667 C c
exoplanets.short_description: Super-Earth in the habitable zone of GJ 667 C.
exoplanets.description: GJ 667 C c orbits a red dwarf star in a triple-star system. It is one of the more interesting super-Earths in a potential habitable zone.

exoplanets.name: Kepler-22 b
exoplanets.short_description: One of the early Kepler habitable-zone finds.
exoplanets.description: Kepler-22 b was discovered by the Kepler Space Telescope and is a larger-than-Earth planet in its star’s habitable zone.

exoplanets.name: Kepler-10 b
exoplanets.short_description: Very hot rocky planet very close to its star.
exoplanets.description: Kepler‑10 b is a dense, rocky exoplanet that orbits extremely close to its star, completing a full orbit in under a day.

exoplanets.name: Kepler-11 f
exoplanets.short_description: One of the compact system of six planets in Kepler‑11.
exoplanets.description: Kepler-11 f is part of a tightly packed planetary system with six transiting planets, all discovered by Kepler.

exoplanets.name: Kepler-11 e
exoplanets.short_description: Largest of the inner five planets in Kepler-11 system.
exoplanets.description: Kepler-11 e is one of the more massive planets in the Kepler-11 system, contributing to the system’s dynamical interactions.

exoplanets.name: HD 189733 b
exoplanets.short_description: Very hot gas giant, well studied atmosphere.
exoplanets.description: HD 189733 b is a well-known hot Jupiter with a very short orbital period, and has been extensively studied for its atmospheric composition (including detection of water vapor, etc.).

exoplanets.name: 55 Cancri e
exoplanets.short_description: Very hot rocky super-Earth with extremely short orbit.
exoplanets.description: 55 Cancri e is an extreme planet: very close to its star, with an orbital period less than a day, and likely rocky, possibly with a lava surface.

exoplanets.name: Gliese 1214 b
exoplanets.short_description: Very dense small planet, possibly with a water-rich envelope.
exoplanets.description: Gliese 1214 b is one of the most studied mini-Neptunes / water world candidates, because its radius and mass suggest it’s not purely rocky.

exoplanets.name: Kepler-62 f
exoplanets.short_description: Potentially habitable super-Earth in Kepler-62 system.
exoplanets.description: Kepler-62 f is in the outer region of its star’s habitable zone. It’s one of the Kepler mission’s most famous potentially habitable planets.

exoplanets.name: Kepler-62 e
exoplanets.short_description: Inner habitable‑zone planet in Kepler-62 system.
exoplanets.description: Kepler-62 e orbits closer than Kepler-62 f and is also considered in studies of potentially habitable worlds.

exoplanets.name: WASP-12 b
exoplanets.short_description: Extremely bloated hot Jupiter, very close to its star.
exoplanets.description: WASP-12 b is one of the most inflated hot Jupiters known — its large radius suggests it’s highly irradiated and strongly heated by its host star.

exoplanets.name: GJ 504 b
exoplanets.short_description: A massive planet imaged directly far from its star.
exoplanets.description: GJ 504 b is a super-Jupiter detected via direct imaging. It orbits at a large separation, making it easier to image directly.

exoplanets.name: Gaia-4 b
exoplanets.short_description: Massive gas giant discovered via Gaia astrometry.
exoplanets.description: Gaia-4 b is a massive planet (super-Jupiter) confirmed by combining Gaia astrometric data and radial velocity. :contentReference[oaicite:3]{index=3}
